assertion.description: It is illegal JSP syntax, which must result in a translation error, to use both an XML element attribute and a <jsp:attribute> standard action to pass the value of the same attribute.
A translation error will result if the custom action invocation has <jsp:attribute> elements but does not define the body using a <jsp:body> element.
White space within the body text of a document is not significant, but is preserved.

Fatal translation failures shall result in the failure of subsequent client requests for the translation target with the appropriate error specification: For HTTP protocols the error status code 500 (Server Error) is returned.
assertion.comment: While this could be deemed as testable, there are several areas in the spec that state a fatal translation error will occur in a specific case. That is where this assertion will be exercised.

assertion.description: HTML comments present within a particular translation unit are treated as uninterpreted template text by the JSP container.
The body content of a JSP comment is ignored completely.

For JSP's in standard syntax, a literal %> is quoted by %\>, a literal <% is quoted by <\%, a single quote (') is quotes as \', a double quite (") is quoted as \", a backslash (\) is quoted as \\, additionally, the entities \' and \" are available to describe single and double quotes.
assertion.comment: Use the examples in JSP.1.6 to create a test.

assertion.description: Objects with page scope are accessible only within the target page they are created. All references to such an object shall be released after the response is sent back to the client from the JSP page or the request is forwareded somwhere else. References to objects with page scope are stored in the 'pageContext' object.

Objects with request scope are accessible from pages processing the same request where they were created. References to the object shall be released after the request is processed. In particular, if the request is forwarded to a resource in the same runtime, the object is still reachable. References to objects with request scope are stored in the 'request' object.

Objects with session scope are accessible from pages processing requests that in the same session as the one in which they were created. It is not legal to define an object with session scope from within a page that is not session-aware. All references to the object shall be released after the associated session ends. References to objects with session scope are stored in the 'session' object associated with the page activation.

Objects with application scope are accessible from pages processing requests that are in the same application as the one in which they were created. Objects with application scope can be defined (and reached) from pages that are not session-aware. References to objects with application scope are stored in the 'application' object associated with a page activation. The 'application' object is the servlet context obtained from the servlet configuration object. All references to the object shall be released when the runtime environment reclaims the ServletContext.

The 'request' implicit object is an instance of javax.servlet.ServletRequest; if the protocol used is HTTP, then the request object is an instance of javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest (request scope).

The 'response' implicit object is an instance of javax.servlet.ServletResponse; if the protocol used is HTTP, then the response object is an instance of javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse (page scope)
The 'pageContext' implicit object is an instance of javax.servlet.jsp.PageContext (page scope).
The 'session' implicit object is an instance of javax.servlet.http.HttpSession and is only valid for HTTP protocols (session scope).
The 'application' implicit object is an instance of javax.servlet.ServletContext (same object as that returned from getServletConfig().getContext(); application scope).
The 'exception' implicit object is an instance of java.lang.Throwable (page scope) and is only available in errro pages.
White space may or may not be present after '<@%' and before '%>' within JSP directives.
Directives do not produce any output into the current 'out' stream.
The page directive can appear multiple times, and is position independent within a given translation unit.
A translation error will occur if the page directive defines duplicate attribute/values within a give translation unit, with the exception of the import attribute.
assertion.comment: NOTE: This may change. Reference PageDirectiveUniqueAttr validity constraint.

assertion.description: The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of the page directive, if true, allows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit.

The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of the page directive, if false, disallows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit and will generate a translation error if they are present.
The default value for 'isScriptingEnabled' of the page directive, if not specified, is true.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive, if true, directs the container to evaluate EL expressions.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive , if false, will result in EL expressions not being evaluated by the container.
If the JSP is part of a Web application that is using a Servlet 2.3 deployment descriptor, the default value for the 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive is false.
assertion.comment: Reference section JSP.2.2.4 Deactivating EL Evaluation

assertion.description: If the JSP is part of a Web application that is using a Servlet 2.4 deployment descriptor, the default value for the 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive is true.
assertion.comment: Reference section JSP.2.2.4 Deactivating EL Evaluation

assertion.description: All scripting languages, specifiable by the page directive's 'language' attribute, must provide some implicit objects that a JSP page author can use in declarations, scriptlets, and expressions (see Section JSP.1.3.8 for list of available implicit objects)

All scripting languages, specifiable by the page directive's 'language' attribute, must expose the Java technology object model to the script environment, especially implicit variables, JavaBeans components properties, and public methods.
It is a fatal translation error for a page directive with a non-"java" language attribute to appear after the first scripting has been encountered.
The only required scripting language value for the 'language' attribute is "java".
The 'extends' attribute of the page directive specifies a fully qualified Java programming language class name, that names the superclass of the class to which this JSP page is transformed

The 'import' attribute of the page directive specifies the fully qualified Java programming language type name denoting a particular type, or of a package name following by the ".*" string, denoting all the public types declared in that package, that shall be imorted by the translated JSP page implementation and is thus available to the scripting language.
The default import list for a JSP page is java.lang.*, javax.servlet.*, javax.servlet.jsp.*, javax.servlet.http.*
The 'session' attribute of the page directive, when true, indicates that the JSP page requires participation in an HTTP session.

The 'session' attribute of the page directive, when false, indicates that the JSP page does not participate in an HTTP session; the 'session' implicit object is not available to the page, and any reference to it within the translation unit will result in a translation error.
If the 'session' attribute of the page directive is not specified by a page directive, then the page will, by default, participate in an HTTP session (default value of true).
If the 'buffer' attribute of the page directive is not specified, no buffering will be performed and all output will be written directly through to the ServletResponse PrintWriter.
The size value specified by the 'buffer' attribute of the page directive must be in kilobytes, and the suffix "kb" is mandatory.
assertion.comment: NOTE: Spec is unclear as to what happens if a different suffix is used, or is not present. Most likely a translation error.

assertion.description: The container must allocate a buffer at least as large as that specified by the 'buffer' attribute of the page directive.
The default buffer size of 8kb will be used if the 'buffer' attribute of the page directive is not specified.
If the 'autoFlush' attribute of the page directive is true, the output will be automatically flushed when the buffer is filled.
If the 'autoFlush' attribute of the page directive is false, an exception will be raised to indicate a buffer overflow.
It is illegal to set the 'autoFlush' attribute of the page directive to false, if the 'buffer' attribute is set to none.
assertion.comment: NOTE: This section needs to be clarified in the spec. Illegal most likely, in this case, means a translation error, but this should be clearly spelled out.

assertion.description: If the 'isThreadSafe' attribute of the page directive is false, the container must serialize requests to the JSP (it should behave like an STM servlet).
assertion.comment: Cannot test isThreadSafe="true" as the keyword 'may' is present. An implementation could potentially serialize requests in this case as well....thought I don't know why they would.

assertion.description: The 'info' attribute of the page directive specifies an arbitrary string that is incorporated into the translated page, that can subsequently be obtained from the page's implementation of Servlet.getServletInfo().

The 'isErrorPage' attribute of the page directive. when true, will cause the implicit script language variable "exception" to be defined and its value is a reference to the offending Throwable from the source JSP page in error.

If the 'isErrorPage' attribute of the page directive is defined as false, then the implicit script language variable "exception" will not be available, and any such reference to this variable will result in a translation error.

The 'errorPage' attribute of the page directive, specifies the URL, either page-relative or context-relative, of a resource to which any Java programming language Throwable object(s) thrown but not caught by the page implementation are forwarded for error processing. The following request attributes will be made available within the error page:
javax.servlet.jsp.jspException - throw Throwable object of the offending exception (for backwards compatibility with JSP 1.2)
javax.servlet.err.exception - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.status_code - as per the Servlet specification
javax.servlet.error.exception_type - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.err.message - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.request_uri - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.servlet_name - as per the Servlet specification.
An instance of javax.servlet.jsp.ErrorData must be provided to the error page.
If the 'errorPage' attribute of the page directive is defined, it will take presendence over any error pages defined in the web application's deployment descriptor.

The character encoding (Content-Type response header) can be in the form of TYPE, or TYPE; Charset=CHARSET, with an optional white space after the ';'. Charset, if present, must be the IANA value for a character encoding. Similarly, if TYPE is a MIME type, see the IANA registry for values.
The default Content-Type for JSP Pages in classic syntax is "text/html".

If a charset portion of the value provided to the 'contentType' attribute is not specified, but the page encoding for the JSP page is specified, then the charset used will be that of the specified page encoding.
If a charset is not provided as part of the 'contentType' attribute value, and the page encoding does not specifiy a type, then the default charset is ISO-8859-1 for JSP pages in classic syntax.
If a charset is not provided as part of the 'contentType' attribute value, and the page encoding does not specifiy a type, then the default charset is UTF-8 for JSP pages in XML syntax.
assertion.comment: Would UTF-16 be valid as well?

assertion.description: The 'pageEncoding' attribute of the page directive specifies the character encoding of the page. The value is in the form of CHARSET which my be the IANA value for a character encoding. If no 'pageEncoding' attribute is specified, the default of ISO-8859-1 will be used.
assertion.comment: What about the default encoding for JSP pages in XML syntax?

assertion.description: It is a translation error for the taglib directive to appear after actions that use the prefix specified by the directive.
The 'uri' attribute of the taglib directive specifies either an absolute or relative URI that uniquely identifies the tag library descriptor associated with this prefix.
assertion.comment: URI and taglibrary determination is defined in Chapter 7

assertion.description: The 'tagdir' attribute of the taglib directive indicates that the specified prefix is to be used to identify tag extensions installed in the /WEB-INF/tags directory or a subdirectory.
assertion.comment: Refer to JSP8.4.3 for more details.

assertion.description: A translation error must occur if the value provided to the 'tagdir' attribute of the taglib directive doesn't start with '/WEB-INF/tags' and point to a directory that exists within the web application.
A translation error must occur if the 'prefix' attribute of the taglib directive is not present.
A translation error must occur if both the 'tagdir' and 'uri' attributes are present in the same taglib directive.
assertion.comment: Refer to EBNF

assertion.description: The 'prefix' attribute of the taglib directive is used to distinguish a custom action, e.g <myPrefix:myTag>.
The value provided to the 'prefix' attribute of the taglib directive must follow the naming convention specified in the XML namespaces specification.
assertion.comment: Marked as not testable as there it could be container specific as to what happens in this case (most likely a translation error if they did check).

assertion.description: It is illegal to provide an empty prefix to the taglib directive.
assertion.comment: Marked as not testable. What exactly does illegal mean? Again, most likely a translation time issue, but would be good to have clarity.

assertion.description: A translation error will occur if the tag name provided in the custom action isn't found in the taglibrary designated by the prefix.

A JSP container can include a mechanism for being notified if an included file changes, so the container can recompile the JSP page. However, the JSP 2.0 specification does not have a way of directing the JSP container that included files have changed.
The 'file' attribute of the include directive specifies the resource to be imported either relative to web appliation context path, or relative to the page performing the include.
The include directive includes content at translation time meaning the bytes of the included resource are directly inserted into the page.
assertion.comment: Could test this by having a resource that checks for an attribute in the request, since it's included in place without including the result, the attribute would be null..

assertion.description: All JSP containers must support scripting elements based on the Java programming language.
assertion.comment: Marked as untestable as this is a blanket assertion that covers who the spec is currently written.

assertion.description: Any other scripting languages that may be supported by a JSP container must support: The manipulation of Java objects; Invocation of methods on Java objects; Catching of Java language excepitons.
A declaration (<% DECL_BODY %>) must be a complete declarative statment, or sequence thereof, according to the syntax of the scripting language specified, otherwise a translation error will occur.
Declartaions do not produce any output into the current out stream.
Declarations are initialized when the JSP page is initialized and are made available to other delcarations, scriptlets, and expressions.

Scriptlets (<% SCRIPTLET_BODY %>) can contain any code framents that are valid for the scripting language specified by the 'language' attribute of the page directive, and are executed at request time in the order that they appear on the JSP page.
An expression element in a JSP page is a scripting language expression that is evaluated and the result is coerced to a String and emitted into the current JspWriter (out) object.

If the result of the expression cannot be coerced to a String, the following must happen: If the problem is detected at translation time, a translation time error shall occur. If the coercion cannot be detected during translation, a ClassCaseException shall be raised at request time.
assertion.comment: This detection mechanism will be container dependant. Cannot test.

assertion.description: Expressions are evaluated left to right in the JSP page.
If an expression appears in more than one run-time attribute, they are evaluated left-to-right in the element.
A translation error will occur if the expression is not a complete expression in the scripting language in which it is written.
Request-time attribute values in the form of '<%= scriptlet_expr %>' are only usable by actions, and cannot be used in directives.
assertion.comment: Mark, you wanted to revisit this....

assertion.description: A translation error will occur if a request-time attribute exception does not appear by itself (multiple expressions, and mixing of expressions and string constands are not permitted).
assertion.comment: I assume this will be a translation error. Correct if necessary.

assertion.description: Any attempt to provide an attribute value via a request-time expression that doesn't accept request-time expressions, will result in a translation error.
A type conversion failure for a static attribute can lead to a failure at either request or translation time.
Conversion of string values to a JavaBean property is done via setAtText(string-literal).
Conversion of string values to boolean or Boolean is performed as indicated in java.lang.Boolean.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to byte or Byte is performed as indiciated in java.lang.Byte.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to char or Character is performed as indicated in String.charAt(0).
Conversion of string values to double or Double is performed as indiciated in java.lang.Double.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to int or Integer is performed as indiciated in java.lang.Integer.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to float or Float is performed as indicated in java.lang.Float.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to long or Long is perfomed as indicated in java.lang.Long.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to short or Short is performed as indicated in java.lang.Short.valueOf(String).
Conversion of string values to Object is performed as if new String(string).
No type conversion is perfomed against requst-time expressions, they are provided to the element as is.
assertion.comment: This seems to indicate that if the underlying attribute being set by this request-time expression doesn't match the type provided by the expression, a runtime exception will be thrown. Good negative test case.

assertion.description: EL is invoked via the construct ${expr}.
If EL is being evaluated by the container, a translation error will occur if an EL expression is provided as a value to an attribute that does not accept request-time expressions.
EL expressions will not be evaluated if the tag body is 'tagdependent'.
A container must support EL expressions provided in template text be it inside the body of a custom or standard action, or in template text outside of any action.
The boolean literals in the EL are 'true' and 'false'
EL integer literals are equivelant to Java integer literals.
assertion.comment: See IntergerLiteral production in JSP.2.13

assertion.description: EL floating point literals are equivelant to Java floating point literals.
assertion.comment: See FloatingPointLiteral production in JSP.2.13

assertion.description: String literals are encapsulated by either double or single quotes (''' or '"' respectively). Quotes need to be escape in the String if the string value enclosed is the same type of quote. Escaping definitions are the same as those defined in JSP.1.6.
The EL null literal is defined as 'null'.
The EL follows ECMAScript in unifying the treatment of the "." and "[]" operators. To evaluate expr-a[expr-b]:
Evaluate expr-a into value-a, if value-a is null, return null.
Evaluate expr-b into value-b, if value-b is null, return null.
If value-a is a Map, and if !value-a.containsKey(value-b) then return null, otherwise, return the value of value-a.get(value-b).
If value-a is a List or array:
If value-b cannot be coerced into an int (using coercion rules) an error occurs.
If value-a.get(value-b) or Array.get(value-a, value-b) throws an ArrayIndexOutofBoundException or IndexOutOfBoundsException, return null.
If value-a.get(value-b) or Array.get(value-a, value-b) throws other exception, error.
Otherwise, return value-a.get(value-b) or Array.get(value-a, value-b) as appropriate.
Otherwise (a JavaBeans object, coerce value-b to String
If value-b is a readable property of value-a, return the result of the getter call.
If value-b is not a readable property of value-a, return error.
If the getter call throws an Exception: error.
Binary operators - A { +,-,* } B
If A or B is null, return 0
If A or B is Float, Double, or a String containing ".", "e", or "E", coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
Otherwise coerce both A and B to Long and apply operator.
If application of operator against A and B results in an exception, error.
Binary operator - A { / or div } B
If A or B is null, return 0
Coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
If application of operator against A and B results in an exception, error.
Binary Operator - A { % or mod } B
If application of operator against A and B results in an exception, error.
Otherwise coerce both A and B to Long and apply operator.
If A or B is Float, Double, or a String containing ".", "e", or "E", coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
If A or B is null, return 0
Unary minus operator - -A
If A is null, return 0
If A is a String:
If A or B is Float, Double, or a String containing ".", "e", or "E", coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
Otherwise coerce both A and B to Long and apply operator.
If application of operator against A and B results in an exception, error.
If A is Byte, Short, Integer, Long, Float, Double:
retain the type and apply the operator.
If application of operator results in exception, error.
Relational operators - A { <,>,<=,=>,lt,gt,le,ge } B
If A and B are equals, and operator is <=, le, >=, or ge, return true, otherwise return false.
If A or B is null, return false.
If A or B is Float or Double coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
If A or B is Byte, Short, Character, Integer, or Long, coerce both A and B to Long and apply operator.
If A is Comparable, and A.compareTo(B) throws an exception, error; otherwise return the result of A.compareTo(B)
If B is Comparable, and B.compareTo(A) throws an exception, error; otherwise return the result of B.compareTo(A)
Otherwise return error.
Relation Operatos - A { ==, !=, eq, ne } B
If A == B, apply operator.
If A or B is null, return false for == (eq), true for != (ne)
If A or B is Float or Double coerce both A and B to Double and apply operator.
If A or B is Byte, Short, Character, Integer, or Long, coerce both A and B to Long and apply operator.
If A or B is Boolean coerce both A and B to Boolean apply operator.
If A or B is String coerce both A and B to String, if error occurs calling A.equals(B), error; otherwise apply operator to result of A.equals(B).
Binary Operator - A { &&, ||, and, or } B
Coerce both A and B to Boolean and apply operator.
Unary operator - { !, not } A
Coerce A to Boolean and apply operator.
Empty operator - empty A
If A is null, return true, otherwise false.
If A is an emtpy String, return true, otherwise false.
If A is an empty array, then return true, otherwise false.
If A is an emtpy Map, then return true, otherwise false.
If A is an empty List, then return true, otherwise false.
Operator precedence (highest to lowest) - [] . then (), then -(unary) not ! emtpy, then * / div % mod, then + - (binary), then < > <= >= lt gt le ge, then == != eq ne, then && and, then || or.
The following words are reserved by the EL, and, or, not, eq, ne, lt, gt, le, ge, true, false, null, instanceof, empty, div, mod and should not be used as identifiers without being quoted.
assertion.comment: Some confusion as to how one would quote this. see EL-24.

assertion.description: If no scope qualifier is added to provided EL expression, the EL will lookup the attribute based on the behavior of PageContext.findAttribute(String), i.e, it will search the PageContext for the attribute first in the page, then request, then session, followed by application scopes and will return the value, otherwise null will be returned.
If the function class, as described in the TLD, is not a public non-abstract class, a translation error will occur.
If the method, as described in the TLD, is not a public static method, a translation error will occur.
If two functions within the same tag library have the same name, a translation error will occur.
EL function invocation semantics:

If the function has no namespace associated, then, if the function is used in an attribute value, assume the namespace as that of the custom action; if the function is used elsewhere, this shall be a translation error.
Locate the TLD associated with the namespace. If none can be found, a translation error shall occur.
Locate the function element with a name subelement with the provided function name. If none can be found, a translation error shall occur.

Locate the public class with name equal to the value of the funcion-class element. Locate the public static method with name and signature equal to the value of the function-signature element. If any of these don't exist, a translation error shall occur.
Evaluate each argument to the corresponding type indicated in the signature.
Evaluate the public static Java method. The resulting type is that of the return value in the function-signature element.
The 'pageContext' implicit object corresponse to the PageContext object.
The 'pageScope' implicit object allows access to page scoped attribute values.
The 'requestScope' implicit object allows access to request scoped attribute values.
The 'sessionScope' implicit object allows access to session scoped attribute values.
The 'applicationScope' implicit object allows access to application scoped attribute values.
The 'param' implicit object allows access to a single parameter value (obtained via ServletRequest.getParameter(String name)).
The 'paramValues' implicit allows access to a String[] of all values for the specified parameter (obtained via ServletRequest.getParameterValues(String name)).
The 'header' implicit object allows access to a single request-header value (obtained by calling HttpServletRequest.getHeader(String name)).
The 'headerValues' implicit object returns the a String[] of all values for the specified header (obtained via HttpServletRequest.getHeaders(String name)).
The 'cookie' implicit object provides access the the named cookie.

If there are multiple cookies identified by the same name, the implementation must return the first cookie in the array, but the cookie order provided to the implementation is currently not specified.
The 'initParam' implicit object provides access to context initialization parameters (obtained via ServletContext.getInitParameter(String name)).
To coerce a value X to type Y
If X is of a primitive type, Let X be the equivalent 'boxed form' of X, otherwise, Let X be the same as X.
If Y is of a primitive type, Let Y be the equivalent 'boxed form' of Y. Otherwise, let Y be the same as Y.
Apply conversion rules.
assertion.comment: ADD DEPENDENCIES

assertion.description: If Y is a primitive type, then the result is found by 'unboxing' the result of the coercion. If the result of the coercion is null, then error.
If Y is not a primitive type, the the result is the result of the coercion.
Coerce A to String
If A is a String: return A
If A is null, return and empty String ("").
If A.toString() throws exception, error.
Otherwise return A.toString()
Coerce A to Number type N
If A is null or "", return 0
If A is Character, convert to short, apply numeric rules below.
If A is a Boolean, then error.
If A is Number type N, return A
If A is a Number, coerce quietly to type N
If A is String, and N.valueOf(A) throws exception, then error.
If A is String, and N.valueOf(A) does not throw an exception, return the value.
All other types will result in an error.
Coerce A to Character
If A is null or "". return (char) 0
If A is Character, then return A
If A is Boolean, error.
If A is Number, coerce quietly to type Short, then return a Character whose numeric value is equivalent to that Short.
If A is String, return A.charAt(0)
All other types will result in an error.
Coerce A to Boolean
If A is null or "", return false
Otherwise if A is Boolean, return A
Otherwise if A is String, and Boolean.valueOf(A) throws exception, error.
Otherwise if A is String , and Bollean.valueOf(A) does not throw exception, return it.
Any other type, return error.
Coerce A to any other type T
If A is null, return null.
If A is assignable to T, coerce quietly.
If A is String, and T has no Property Editor, then if A is "" return null, otherwise error.
If A is String, and T's PropertyEditor throws exception, then if A is "" return null, otherwise error.
Otherwise, apply T's PropertyEditor
Otherwise, error

A jsp-property-group will apply a set of properties to a specific group of resources identified via a URL pattern. If a resource matches URL patterns in more than one group, the pattern that is the most specific applies (follows the rules for URL pattern matching as defined in the Servlet Specification).

EL expression evaluation can be activated for a group of JSP resources as specified by the URL pattern using the <el-enabled> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element. If the value provided is true, EL expressions will be evaluated.

EL expression evaluation can be deactivated for a group of JSP resources as specified by the URL pattern using the <el-enabled> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element. If the value provided is false, EL expressions will be treated as template text (or uninterpreted attribute values).

Scripting elements can be allowed for a group of JSP resources as specified by the URL pattern using the <scripting-enabled> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element. If the value is true, scripting elements such as scriptlets, classic expressions, and declarations will be allowed.

Scripting elements can be disallowed for a group of JSP resources as specified by the URL pattern using the <scripting-enabled> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element. If the value is false, scripting elements such as scriptlets, classic expressions, and declarations present within this group will result in translation errors for any page containing such elements.
A translation error will occur if the target translation unit specifies a different page encoding than that specified in the <page-encoding> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element.
A translation error will not occur if the target translation unit specifies the same page encoding as that specified in the <page-encoding> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element.

The <include-prelude> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element defines a context-relative path to a resource within the web application that will be automatically included into the beginning of all JSP resources of the particular group.

The <include-coda> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element defines a context-relative path to a resource within the web application that will be automatically included into the end of all JSP resources of the particular group.

In both cases, <include-prelude> and <include-coda>, if there are multiple entries of these elements they will be included into the JSP page in the order they appear within the <jsp-property-group> element.
The <is-xml> subelement of the <jsp-property-group> element is used to denote that a group of files are JSP doucments, and thus must be interpreted as XML documents.
If 'true', the files denoted must be interpreted as XML documents.
If 'false', the files in the associated property group are assumed not to be JSP documents.
If the <is-xml> subelement is false within one property-group, but another property-group identifying the same set of files sets <is-xml> to true, then the files will be processed as XML documents.
If the <jsp:useBean> action is used within a scriptless context, then the variable exported will be available via EL expressions.
If both 'type' and 'class' attributes of the <jsp:useBean> standard action are present, and 'class' is not assignable to 'type', a translation error will occur.
A translation error will occur of both the 'beanName' and 'class' attributes are specified within the same useBean action.
assertion.comment: Reference StdActionAttributesValid VC

assertion.description: The 'beanName' attribute can accept dynamic attribute values (RT or EL).
The 'beanName' attribute of the <jsp:useBean> action must be of the form "a.b.c", which can resolve to:
A java class that will be resolved in the current ClassLoader
A serialized bean instance in the form similar to a/b/c.ser that will be resolved in the current ClassLoader.

If the resource identified by 'beanName' attribute of the <jsp:useBean> action cannot be resolved, a request-time exception, as indicated in the semantics of the instantiate() method of the java.beans.Beans class, will be raised.

The 'id' attribute of the <jsp:useBean> actions provides the name used to identify the object instance in the specified scopes namespace, and also the scripting variable name declared and initialized with that reference.
The name specified is case sensitive.
The value's provided to the 'id' attribute of the <jsp:useBean> action must be unique within the given translation unit. Any duplicate id's found, will result in a translation error.
The 'scope' attribute of the <jsp:useBean> action specifies the scope or namespace within which the object reference is available.
assertion.comment: See section JSP.1.8.2 for lifecycle sematics of the scopes described below.

assertion.description: If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default scope will be 'page'.
If a value of 'page' is provided to the 'scope' attribute, the object will be exported to the page scope.
If a value of 'request' is provided to the 'scope' attribute, the object will be exported to the request scope.
If a value of 'session' is provided to the 'scope' attribute, the object will be exported to the session scope.
If a value of 'application' is provided to the 'scope' attribute, the object will be exported to the application scope.
If the value provided to the 'scope' attribute is not one of 'page', 'request', 'session', or 'application', a translation error will occur.
assertion.comment: CLR-2

assertion.description: A translation error will occur if the <jsp:useBean> action attempts to export an object to the session scope and sessions have been disabled for the target page.

For all scopes, it is illegal to change the value of an instance object associated with a particular scope, such that its new runtime type is a subset of the type(s) of the object previously so associated.
Sematics: The actions performed in jsp:useBean action are:
The action searches for objects in scope, the search is done synchronized per scope namespace to avoid non-deterministic behavior.
assertion.comment: jsp:useBean sematics

assertion.description: A scripting language variable of the specified type (if given) or class (if type is not give) is defined with the given 'id' int he current lexical scope of the scripting language.

If the 'class' attribute of the action is provided a value that referrs to an Abstract class, an Interface, or a class with no public no-arg constructor, the implementation may throw a java.lang.InstantiationException, or may raise a translation error.
assertion.comment: jsp:useBean semantics

assertion.description: If the object, as identified by the 'id' and 'scope' attributes of the action is found, and the object is not castable to the type as specified by the 'type' attribute, a java.lang.ClassCastException shall occur. The action will cease processing at this point.
assertion.comment: jsp:useBean semantics

assertion.description: If the jsp:useBean has a non-empty body, it will be ignored (i.e. template text, as well as standard and custom actions will not be processed) and the action will cease processing.
If the specified object is not found in the specified scope, and neither 'class' nor 'beanName' are given, a java.lang.InstantiationException shall occur and the action will cease processing.

If the specified object is not found in the specified scope, and the 'class' attribute specifies a non-abstract class that defines a public no-args constructor, then the class is instantiated and the object reference is associated with a scripting variable name as identified by the 'id' attribute and exported to the scope as indicated by the 'scope' attribute.
If the action has a non-empty body, then the body will be processed. Template text will be passed through, and standard and custom actions will be processed by the container.

If the specified object is not found in the specified scope, and the 'beanName' attribute is specified, then the method instantiate() of java.beans.Beans will be invoked with the ClassLoader of the Servlet object with the value of the 'beanName' attribute as the argument. If the method succeeds, the object refernece is associated with the scripting variable identified by the 'id' attribute and expored to the scope as indicated by the 'scope' attribute.
If the action has a non-empty body, then the body will be processed. Template text will be passed through, and standard and custom actions will be processed by the container.
The body of the action can be specified via the <jsp:body> action.
The <jsp:setProperty> action sets the values of properties in a Bean.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of a Bean instance defined by a <jsp:useBean> action or some other action.
The Bean instance must contain the property that is being set.
If the object in which the property will be set was not introduced before the jsp:setProperty call, the container implementation is recommended, but not required to raise a translation error.
The 'property' attribute specifies the bean property whose value is to be set.

If '*' is provided to the property attribute, the action will iterate over the current ServletRequest parameters matching parameter names and value types(s) to property names and setter method type(s), setting each matched property to the value of the matching parameter.
If a parameter has a value of "", the corresponding property is not modified.
The 'param' attribute specifies the name of the request parameter whose value will be given to a Bean property.
If the 'param' attribute is omitted from the action, the request parameter name is assumed to be the same as the Bean property name.
If the param is not set in the Request object, or if it has the value of "", the action has no effect (a noop).
A translation error will occur if both the 'param' and 'value' attributes both specified within the same action.
The 'value' attribute specifies the value to assign to the given property.
The 'value' attribute can accept request-time expressions (RT and EL).
The 'value' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
A translation error will occur if the 'property' attribute value is '*', and any other attributes are provided to the action.
When assigning values from a parameter in the request object, the conversions described in JSP.1.14.2.1 are applied, using the target property to determine the target type.
When assigning from a value given as a String constand, the conversions described in JSP.1.14.2.1 are applied, using the target property to determine the target type.
When assigning from a value given as a request-time attribute, no type conversions are applied, as indicated in Section JSP.1.14.2.2
When assiging values to indexed propertyes the values must be an array; the rules, as indicated in Section JSP.1.14.2.2 apply.
The <jsp:getProperty> action places the value of a Bean instance property, converted to a String, into the implicit out object.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of the Bean instance from which the property is obtained.
The 'property' attribute specifies the name of the property to access within the specified Bean instance.

If the object referenced by the 'name' attribute was not 'introduced' via <jsp:useBean> or a custom action with an associated VariableInfo entry, the container implementation, is recommended (but nore required) to raise a translation error, since this page implementation is in violation of the specification.
The conversion to String is done as in the println() methods, i.e. the toStrint() method of the object is used for Object instances, and primitive types are converted directly.
A translation error will occur if the 'property' attribute is not specified within the action.
The <jsp:include> action provides for inclusion of static and dynamic resources int he same context as the current page.
assertion.comment: Perhaps base a set of tests based on the examples for <jsp:include>

assertion.description: The 'page' attribute specifies a relative URL (either page or context relative) to a resource within the same web application context.
The 'flush' attribute, if true, will immediately flush the buffer prior to inclusion.
The 'flush' attribute, if false, will not flush the buffer prior to inclusion.
The default value for the 'flush' attribute is false.
A tranlsation error will occur of the 'page' attribute is not specified.
An included page only has access to the JspWriter object (out).
Any attempt by an included page to set headers, will be ignored by the container.
An include action may use <jsp:param> action present as body content to provide request parameters for the included resource.
The 'page' attribute can accept request-time expressions (either classic RT or EL).
The 'page' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
The <jsp:forward> action will forward the current request to the target resource, be it a static resource, a JSP page, or a servlet class in the same context as the current page.
The 'page' attribute specifies the target resource (either via a page relative or context relative path) to which to dispatch the current request to.
The request object will be adjusted according to the value of the page attribute.
assertion.comment: Untestable as this is vague.

assertion.description: If the page is buffered, the buffer is cleard prior to forwarding.
If the page output is buffered, and the buffered was flushed, and attempt to forward the request will result in an IllegalStateException
If the page output was unbuffered and anthing has been written to it, an attempt to forward the request will result in an IllegalStateException.
The forward action can accept <jsp:param> actions as body content to provide request parameters for the target resource.
A translation error will occur of the 'page' attribute is omitted from the action.
The 'page' attribute accepts request-time expressions (either classic RT or EL expressions).
The 'page' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
The <jsp:param> action specifies key/value information.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of the parameter.
The 'value' attribute specifies the value for this particular parameter.
A translation error will occur if the <jsp:param> action is not a child of a <jsp:include>, <jsp:forward>, or a <jsp:params> action.

If used in conjunction with <jsp:include> or <jsp:forward>, the target resource will see the original request object including the augmented parameters provided by the <jsp:param> action, with the new parameters taking precendence over the originals.
If used in conjuntion with <jsp:include> or <jsp:forward>, the new parameters will not apply after the action returns.
assertion.comment: This is not testable for <jsp:forward>

assertion.description: The 'value' attribute can accept request-time (either classic RT or EL) expressions.
A translation error will occur if either the 'name' or 'value' attributes is not specified.
The 'value' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
The <jsp:plugin> action enables an JSP page author to generate plugin re-lated HTML.
Depending on the browser's user-agent, the action will generate either an HTML OBJECT or EMBED tag.
The <jsp:params> action specifies a set of parameters (each parameter is defined by a one or more <jsp:param> actions).
A translation error will occur of the <jsp:params> action is present, but contains no <jsp:param> sub-actions.
A translation error will occur if the <jsp:params> action is used in any other context outside of the <jsp:plugin> action.
The <jsp:fallback> attribute specifies alternate text if the plugin cannot be started.
The alternate text generated by the <jsp:fallback> action is provided as body content.
The body of the <jsp:fallback> attribute can be provided via the <jsp:body> action.
The use of <jsp:fallback> in any other context (either independent action or child or another) will result in a translation error.
The 'type' attribute will specifiy the type of component will be either an applet or a Bean.
A translation error will occur if a value other than 'bean' or 'applet' is provided to the action.f
The 'code' attribute specifies the code attribute of the object per the HTML specification.
The 'codebase' attribute specifies the codebase of the object per the HTML specification.
The 'align' attribute provides the alignment of the object per the HTML specification.
The 'archive' attribute provides the archive used by the object per the HTML specification.
The 'height' attribute specifies the height of the object per the HTML specification
The 'height' attribute accepts request-time (either classic RT or EL) expressions.
The 'height' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
The 'hspace' attribute specifies the hspace of the object per the HTML specification.
The 'jreversion' attribute specifies the version of JRE required for the object to fuction properly.
If the 'jreversion' attribute is not specified, the default version present in the generated HTML will be "1.2".
The 'name' attribute specifies the logical name for the embedded object per the HTML specification.
The 'vspace' attribute specifies the vspace to be used by the embedded object per the HTML specification.
The 'title' attribute specifies the title of the embedded object per the HTML specification.
The 'width' attribute specifies the width of the embedded object per the HTML specification.
The 'width' attribute can accep request-time (either classic RT or EL) expressions.
The 'width' attribute can be described via the <jsp:attribute> standard action.
The 'nspluginurl' attribute specifies the URL where the JRE plugin can be downloaded for netscape.
If the 'nspluginurl' attribute is not specified, the url returned in the generated HTML is implementation specific.
The 'iepluginurl' attribute specifies the URL where the JRE plugin for IE can be downloaded.
If the 'iepluginurl' attribute is not specified, the url returned in the generated HTML is implementation specific.
A translation error will occur if the 'code' attribute is not specified.
A translation error will occur if the 'codebase' attribute is not specified.
The <jsp:attribute> action allows a page author to define the value of a tag handler attribute in an XML element instead of in the value of the XML attribute.
The 'name' attribute specifies the name of the attribute of the attribute for the tag being invoked.
If the attribute does not accept dynamic attributes, and the specified attribute name doesn't exist in the surrounding action, a translation error will occur.
A translation error will occur if both an XML element attribute and a <jsp:attribute> element are used to specify the value for the same attribute.
A translation error will occur if the 'name' attribute is not specified.

If the value provided to the 'name' attribute is a QName with a prefix that doesn't match that of the applicable action, and the action does not accept dynamic attributes, a translation error will occur.
Any attempt to use the <jsp:attribute> action outside of a JSP standard action, or a JSP custom action must result in a translation error.
JSP containers must support the use of <jsp:attribute> for both Classic and Simple Tag Handlers.

For custom action (both Classic and Simple) attribute types of type javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.JspFragment, the container must create a JspFragment out of the boyd of the <jsp:attribute> action and pass it to the tag handler.
A translation error will occur if the attribute type is javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.JspFragment, and the body of the <jsp:attribute> action is not scriptless.

If the custom action accepts dynamic attributes, and the name of the attribute is not one explicity indeicated for the tag, then the container will evaluate the body of <jsp:attribute> and assign the computed value to the attribute using the dynamic attribute machinery.

For standard or custom actions attributes that accept a runtime expression value, the container must evaluated the body of the <jsp:attribute> action and use the result of theis evaluation as the value of the attribute.
A translation error must occur if the body of the <jsp:attribute> action contains anything but template text when the standard or custom action attributes do not accept dynamic values.
If the enclosing action is <jsp:element> then the values of the name attribute and the boyd of the attribute will be used to construct a new element dynamically.
If the body of the <jsp:attribute> is empty, it is the equivalent of specifying "" (an empty String) as the value of the attribute
The body of the <jsp:body> action can be specified via the <jsp:body> action.
The <jsp:body> allows for the explicit definition of a body for a custom action.
The 'value' attribute allows the author to provide the body of the action as an attribute value.
The value of this attribute must evaluate to an instance of javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.JspFragment, otherwise a JspException must result.
If the 'value' attribute of <jsp:body> is specified and the action has a body, translation error must occur.
If the 'value' attribute of <jsp:body> is not specified, and the action has no body, a translation error must occur.
The 'value' attribute can accept dynamic attribute values (both EL and RT).

If the 'value' attribute is used to specify the value of a custom action defined using a Classic Tag Handler, the container must generate code to invoke the gragment, sending the output to the current JspWriter, and passing in a Map of paramters for all AT_BEGIN and NESTED variables provided by the tag handler.
Any attempt to use the value attribute to define the body of a standard action must result in a translation error.
The <jsp:invoke> action will invoke the specified fragment and write the result to the current JspWriter, or to scoped variable.
The 'fragment' attribute specifies the name used to identify this fragment during this tag invocation.
The 'varReader' attribute specifies the scoped attribute in which to store the result of the fragment invocation.
The type of the scoped attribute must be java.io.Reader.
The 'var' attribute specifies the scoped attribute in which to store the result of the fragment invocation.
The type of the scoped attribute must be java.lang.String.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to store the attribute specified by the 'varReader' attribute.
A value of 'page' will result in the attribute being stored in the page scope.
A value of 'request' will result in the attribute being stored in the request scope.
A value of 'session' will result in the attribute being stored in the session scope.
A value of 'application' will result in the attribute being stroed in the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default value of 'page' will be used.
/XXX FIXME What happens if client not in session and session scope is specified.
A translation error will occur if the scope attribute is provided an invalid value.
A translation error will occur of the <jsp:invoke> is present outside of a tag file context.
If neither 'var' nor 'varReader' attribute is not specified, the result of the invocation will be written to the current JspWriter.
When the 'varReader' attribute is specified, the object must produce the content sent by the fragment by the provided writer.
When the 'var' attribute is specified, the object must store the content sent by the fragment in a String object.
A translation error must occur of both 'var' and 'varReader' are specified within the same action.

When 'varReader' attribute is specified, the Reader exported must be resettable, such that if its reset() method is called, the result of the invoked fragment must be able to be read again without re-executing the fragment.
assertion.comment: check object references manually between invocations to ensure that we're not getting new reader objects.

assertion.description: A translation error will occur if there is not a one-to-one correlation between the number of <jsp:param> elements present within the body of the <jsp:invoke> action and the required variables as defined by the 'variable' directive.
A translation error must not occur if a <jsp:param> element appears without a corresponding variable directive.
A translation error will occur if the body of the <jsp:invoke> action contains body content other than white space and <jsp:param> subelements.
A translation error will occur of the 'fragment' attribute is not specified for a particular <jsp:invoke> action.
The <jsp:doBody> standard action invokes the body of a tag.
The 'varReader' attribute specifies the scoped attribute in which to store the result of the body invocation.
The type of the scoped attribute must be java.io.Reader.
The 'var' attribute specifies the scoped attribute in which to store the result of the body invocation.
The type of the scoped attribute must be java.lang.String.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope in which to store the attribute specified by the 'varReader' attribute.
A value of 'page' will result in the attribute being stored in the page scope.
A value of 'request' will result in the attribute being stored in the request scope.
A value of 'session' will result in the attribute being stored in the session scope.
A value of 'application' will result in the attribute being stroed in the application scope.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default value of 'page' will be used.
/XXX FIXME What happens if client not in session and session scope is specified.
A translation error will occur if the 'scope' attribute is provided an invalid value.
A translation error will occur if the 'var' and 'varReader' attributes are both specified within the same action.
A translation error will occur if the <jsp:doBody> action contains body content other than white space and <jsp:param> subelements.

A translation error will occur if there is not a one-to-one correlation between the number of <jsp:param> elements present within the body of the <jsp:doBody> action and the required fragment inputs as defined by the 'variable' directive.
A translation error must not occur if a <jsp:param> element appears without a corresponding variable directive.
A translation error must occur if a <jsp:param> is specified with the same name as a variable with a scope of AT_BEGIN, or NESTED.
A translation error must not occur if a <jsp:param> is specified with the same name as a variable with a scope of AT_END.
A JSP document is identified though the following algorithm in order or precedence:
If a <jsp-property-group> explicitly identifies a set of files as JSP Documents (through the use of <is-xml>), then that indication overrides any other determination.
If there is no explicit association and the extension is ".jspx", then the file is a JSP document.
If the file is explicitly or implicitly defined as a JSP page and the top element is a jsp:root element, then the file is identified as a JSP doucment (provided for backwards compatibility).
It is a translation error for a file that id identified as a JSP document to not be a well-formed XML document.
RT expressions must be expressed in JSP Documents using the following syntax: "%= expr %".
Whitespace after the starting '%=' and before the ending '%" is optional.
If an expression appears in more than one run-time attribute, they are evaluated left-to-right in the element.
It is legal to use any prefix for JSP standard actions as long as the require URI, 'http://java.sun.com/JSP/page" is associated with the specified prefix.
XXX FIXME ----- URN:JSPTLD STUFF
XXX FIXME -- jsp:root element
The jsp:directive.page, a child element of the jsp:root element, defines page level properties with the same semantics as the page directive in JSP syntax.
jsp:directive.page can appear multiple times, and is position independent within a given translation unit.
A translation error will occur if jsp:directive.page defines duplicate attribute/values within a give translation unit, with the exception of the import attribute.
assertion.comment: NOTE: This may change. Reference PageDirectiveUniqueAttr validity constraint.

assertion.description: The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page, if true, allows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit.

The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page, if false, disallows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit and will generate a translation error if they are present.
The default value for 'isScriptingEnabled' of jsp:directive.page, if not specified, is true.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page, if true, directs the container to evaluate EL expressions.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page , if false, will result in EL expression not being evaluated by the container.
If the JSP is part of a Web application that is using a Servlet 2.3 deployment descriptor, the default value for the 'isELEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page is false.
assertion.comment: Reference section JSP.2.2.4 Deactivating EL Evaluation

assertion.description: If the JSP is part of a Web application that is using a Servlet 2.4 deployment descriptor, the default value for the 'isELEnabled' attribute of jsp:directive.page is true.
assertion.comment: Reference section JSP.2.2.4 Deactivating EL Evaluation

assertion.description: All scripting languages, specifiable by jsp:directive.page's 'language' attribute, must provide some implicit objects that a JSP page author can use in declarations, scriptlets, and expressions (see Section JSP.1.3.8 for list of available implicit objects)

All scripting languages, specifiable by jsp:directive.page's 'language' attribute, must expose the Java technology object model to the script environment, especially implicit variables, JavaBeans components properties, and public methods.
It is a fatal translation error for a page directive with a non-"java" language attribute to appear after the first scripting has been encountered.
The only required scripting language value for the 'language' attribute is "java".
The 'extends' attribute of jsp:directive.page specifies a fully qualified Java programming language class name, that names the superclass of the class to which this JSP page is transformed

The 'import' attribute of jsp:directive.page specifies the fully qualified Java programming language type name denoting a particular type, or of a package name following by the ".*" string, denoting all the public types declared in that package, that shall be imorted by the translated JSP page implementation and is thus available to the scripting language.
The default import list for a JSP page is java.lang.*, javax.servlet.*, javax.servlet.jsp.*, javax.servlet.http.*
The 'session' attribute of jsp:directive.page, when true, indicates that the JSP page requires participation in an HTTP session.

The 'session' attribute of jsp:directive.page, when false, indicates that the JSP page does not participate in an HTTP session; the 'session' implicit object is not available to the page, and any reference to it within the translation unit will result in a translation error.
If the 'session' attribute of jsp:directive.page is not specified, then the page will, by default, participate in an HTTP session (default value of true).
If the 'buffer' attribute of jsp:directive.page is not specified, no buffering will be performed and all output will be written directly through to the ServletResponse PrintWriter.
The size value specified by the 'buffer' attribute of jsp:directive.page must be in kilobytes, and the suffix "kb" is mandatory.
assertion.comment: NOTE: Spec is unclear as to what happens if a different suffix is used, or is not present. Most likely a translation error.

assertion.description: The container must allocate a buffer at least as large as that specified by the 'buffer' attribute of jsp:directive.page.
The default buffer size of 8kb will be used if the 'buffer' attribute of the page directive is not specified.
If the 'autoFlush' attribute of the page directive is true, the output will be automatically flushed when the buffer is filled.
If the 'autoFlush' attribute of the page directive is false, an exception will be raised to indicate a buffer overflow.
It is illegal to set the 'autoFlush' attribute of jsp:directive.page to false, if the 'buffer' attribute is set to none.
assertion.comment: NOTE: This section needs to be clarified in the spec. Illegal most likely, in this case, means a translation error, but this should be clearly spelled out.

assertion.description: If the 'isThreadSafe' attribute of jsp:directive.page is false, the container must serialize requests to the JSP (it should behave like an STM servlet).
assertion.comment: Cannot test isThreadSafe="true" as the keyword 'may' is present. An implementation could potentially serialize requests in this case as well....thought I don't know why they would.

assertion.description: The 'info' attribute of jsp:directive.page specifies an arbitrary string that is incorporated into the translated page, that can subsequently be obtained from the page's implementation of Servlet.getServletInfo().

The 'isErrorPage' attribute of jsp:directive.page. when true, will cause the implicit script language variable "exception" to be defined and its value is a reference to the offending Throwable from the source JSP page in error.

If the 'isErrorPage' attribute of jsp:directive.page is defined as false, then the implicit script language variable "exception" will not be available, and any such reference to this variable will result in a translation error.

The 'errorPage' attribute of jsp:directive.page, specifies the URL, either page-relative or context-relative, of a resource to which any Java programming language Throwable object(s) thrown but not caught by the page implementation are forwarded for error processing. The following request attributes will be made available within the error page:
javax.servlet.jsp.jspException - throw Throwable object of the offending exception (for backwards compatibility with JSP 1.2)
javax.servlet.err.exception - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.status_code - as per the Servlet specification
javax.servlet.error.exception_type - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.err.message - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.request_uri - as per the Servlet specification.
javax.servlet.error.servlet_name - as per the Servlet specification.
An instance of javax.servlet.jsp.ErrorData must be provided to the error page.
If the 'errorPage' attribute of jsp:directive.page is defined, it will take presendence over any error pages defined in the web application's deployment descriptor.

The character encoding (Content-Type response header) can be in the form of TYPE, or TYPE; Charset=CHARSET, with an optional white space after the ';'. Charset, if present, must be the IANA value for a character encoding. Similarly, if TYPE is a MIME type, see the IANA registry for values.
The default Content-Type for JSP Pages in XML syntax is "text/xml".

If a charset portion of the value provided to the 'contentType' attribute is not specified, but the page encoding for the JSP page is specified, then the charset used will be that of the specified page encoding.
If a charset is not provided as part of the 'contentType' attribute value, and the page encoding does not specifiy a type, then the default charset is ISO-8859-1 for JSP pages in classic syntax.
If a charset is not provided as part of the 'contentType' attribute value, and the page encoding does not specifiy a type, then the default charset is UTF-8 for JSP pages in XML syntax.
assertion.comment: Would UTF-16 be valid as well?

assertion.description: The 'pageEncoding' attribute of jsp:directive.page specifies the character encoding of the page. The value is in the form of CHARSET which my be the IANA value for a character encoding. If no 'pageEncoding' attribute is specified, the default of ISO-8859-1 will be used.
assertion.comment: What about the default encoding for JSP pages in XML syntax?

assertion.description: A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:directive.page element within a JSP page.
The jsp:directive.include element, like the include directive, is used to subsitute test and/or code during JSP page translation and has the same semantics as the include directive for JSP pages.
The jsp:directive:include element can appear anywhere within a JSP document.
assertion.comment: A assume that this means it's legal to use without it being a child of <jsp:root>? If not, this should be clarified.

assertion.description: A JSP container can include a mechanism for being notified if an included file changes, so the container can recompile the JSP page. However, the JSP 2.0 specification does not have a way of directing the JSP container that included files have changed.
The 'file' attribute of jsp:directive.include specifies the resource to be imported either relative to web appliation context path, or relative to the page performing the include.
The jsp:directive.include element includes content at translation time meaning the bytes of the included resource are directly inserted into the page.
assertion.comment: Could test this by having a resource that checks for an attribute in the request, since it's included in place without including the result, the attribute would be null..

assertion.description: A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:directive.include element within a JSP page.
The jsp:declaration element is used to declare scripting language constructs that are available to all other scripting elements and follows the same semantics as declarations in standard JSP syntax.

A declaration (<jsp:declaration>DECL_BODY</jsp:declaration>) must be a complete declarative statment, or sequence thereof, according to the syntax of the scripting language specified, otherwise a translation error will occur.
Declartaions do not produce any output into the current out stream.
Declarations are initialized when the JSP page is initialized and are made available to other delcarations, scriptlets, and expressions.
A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:declaration element within a JSP page.
A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:declaration element within a JSP page.
The jsp:scriptlet element are program fragments with the same semantics as scriptlets in standard JSP syntax.

Scriptlets (<jsp:scriptlet>SCR_BODY</jsp:scriptlet>) can contain any code framents that are valid for the scripting language specified by the 'language' attribute of the page directive, and are executed at request time in the order that they appear on the JSP page.
A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:scriptlet element within a JSP page.
The jsp:expression element is used to describe complete expressions in the scripting language that get evaluated at response time. The semantics are the same as expressions in standard JSP syntax.
The result of the expression is coerced to a String and emitted into the current JspWriter (out) object.

If the result of the expression cannot be coerced to a String, the following must happen: If the problem is detected at translation time, a translation time error shall occur. If the coercion cannot be detected during translation, a ClassCaseException shall be raised at request time.
assertion.comment: This detection mechanism will be container dependant. Cannot test.

assertion.description: Expressions are evaluated left to right in the JSP document.
A translation error will occur if the expression is not a complete expression in the scripting language in which it is written.
A JSP container must support the presence of the jsp:expression element within a JSP page.
The jsp:element element is used to dynamically define an XML element
The name of the element can be provided via the 'name' attribute.
The value of the 'name' attribute can be provided via the jsp:attribute element.
The body of the jsp:element element will be the body of the generated element.
The body of the jsp:element element can be provided by the jsp:body element.
JSP containers must support the presence of the jsp:element within standard JSP pages.
The jsp:text element can be used to enclose template text that will be emitted to the current JspWriter (retaining any whitespace within the element).
JSP contianer's must support the presence of jsp:text elements within standard JSP files.
Any elements that are not standard or custom actions are to be passed to the current JspWriter after whitespace processing.
The following steps must be taken by containers when converting a JSP document to it's internal XML view:
Expand all include directives into the JSP framgments they include.
Add the jsp:id attribute
The following steps must be taken by a container to convert a JSP page into its XML view:
Expand all include directives into the JSP framgments the include.
Add a jsp:root element as the root, with appropriate xmlns:jsp attribute, and conver the taglib directive into xmlns:attributes of the jsp:root element.
Convert declarations, scriptlets, and expressions into their equivalent XML forms.
JSP declarations are translated into jsp:declaration elements.
JSP scriptlets are translated into jsp:scriptlet elements.
JSP expressions are translated into jsp:expression elements.
Convert request-time attribute expressions into their equivalent XML forms.
Convert JSP quotations to XML quitations.
Create jsp:text elements for all template text.
Add the jsp:id attribute.
JSP comments (<%-- comment --%>) are not passed through to the XML view of a JSP page.
JSP page directives are translated into <jsp:directive.page> elements.
JSP taglib directives are translated into xmlns:prefix attributes of the jsp:root element.
As of JSP 2.0, the JSP container must support the jsp:id attribute which is only present in the XML view of a JSP page to improve the quality of translation time errors.
Scripting variables can be defined in one of two ways:
Directly within the TLD for a particular action via the <variable> element.
assertion.comment: See appendix D and E for TLD info.

assertion.description: Using a subclass of the TagExtraInfo interface, specifically providing a method body to the getVariableInfo() call.

A translation error must occur if a piece of JSP code that is to be translated into a JSPFragment (any JSP code in the body of a named attribute (<jsp:attribute), that is declared to be a fragment in the TLD, or for the body of any tag handled by a Simple Tag Handler).
A tag library can define listener classes (See Servlet.2.4 specification) which will be instantiated and registered by the JSP container.
Listeners must be instantiated before the start of the application, however, the order in which listeners are registered is undefined.

When tag libraries are deployed in a JSP container as a JAR file, the standard JAR conventions described in the Servlet 2.4 specification apply, including the conventions for dependencies on extensions.
assertion.comment: Need to reference Servlet assertion ID's once created.

assertion.description: Packaged tag libraries must have at least one tag library descript file.
assertion.comment: Negative test: package the classes for a few tags, and then try to access via a JSP page. Should result in a translation error. Silly test, but I guess it works.

assertion.description: Both classic and simple tag handlers (implemented in either Java or as tag files) can be packaged together in the same JAR file.
If a JSP container cannot locate a TLD resource path for a given URI, a fatal translation error shall result.
If the URI resolves to two different TLD resource paths, a translation error will occur.
A TLD must end with the extension ".tld" to be recognized by the container.
assertion.comment: Again, a negative test where the TLD ends in say .tlv and a JSP tries to use a tag defined therein, a translation error will be raised.

assertion.description: When taglibraries are deployed in a JAR file, the TLDs must be present in the META-INF directory in order to be recognized by the container.
assertion.comment: Negative test...same as above. Positive tests for this will be further down the list.

assertion.description: When deployed directly in the web application, the TLD's must be be in the WEB-INF directory, or some directory thereof.

A translation error will occur if the TLD resource path doesn't ultimately resolve directly to a TLD within the web application, or to a JAR file that has the taglib.tld file in the META-INF directory of the JAR.
Explicit taglib map entries between URI's and TLD resource paths can be described using taglib elements of the Web Application Deployment descriptor (web.xml).
Implicit taglib map entries can be described via a TLD file(s) located in the META-INF directory of the JAR file (TLD is not named taglib.tld).

Each TLD files is examined. If it has a <uri> element, then a new <taglib> element is created, with a <taglib-uri> subelement whose value is that of the <uri> element, and with a <taglib-location> subelement that refers to the TLD file.
If the created <taglib> element has a different <taglib-uri> to any in the taglib map, it is added to the map.
The JSP container may "know of" some specific URIs and may provide alternate implementations for the tag libraries described by these URI's.

When the container does provide an alternate implementation, the implementation must provide the same behavior as that described by the required, portable tag library description described by the URI.

A JSP container must always use the mapping specified for a URI in the web.xml deployment descriptor if present. If the deployer wishes to use the platform-specific implementation of the well-known URI, the mapping for that URI should be removed at deployment time.
The <taglib-uri> element may be URI of the following types:
An absolute URI.
A context-relative URI (URI starting with '/').
A page-relative URI (URI that doesn't start with '/').
If the <taglib-location> sublement is a relative URI without a leading slash, the resolution of the taglib location will be relative to /WEB-INF.
The result of the resolution will be a context-relative path (starts with "/").
The following describes the resolution process of the taglib directive to compute the TLD resource path.

If the URI is an absolute URI, check the taglib map for an entry whose URI is the specified absolute URI. If found, the corresponding taglib location is the TLD resource path. The taglib will be usable in the page.
If the absolute URI is not found in the taglib map, a translation error will occur.

If the URI is a context-relative path (URI starts with '/'), look in taglib amp for an entry whose taglib URI matchs the provided URI. If found, the corresponding location is the TLD resource path. The tag library will be available to the page
If the context-relative URI is not found in the taglib map, then the URI provided by the taglib directive is the TLD resource path.

If at translation time, the resource (either a TLD or a JAR where taglib.tld is in the META-INF directory) doesn't exist as specified by the provided context-relative path, a translation error will occur.

If the URI is a page-relative path (the URI doens't start with a '/') look in the taglib map for the same page-relative path. If found, the correspoding taglib location in the map is the TLD resource path. The tag library will be available to the page.

If the page-relative URI is not found in the taglib map, resolve the page relative path to the current JSP page where the directive appears. This will be used as the TLD resource path. If the resource is found at the resolved location, the tag library will be available to the page.
If, at translation time, the resource identified by the resolved page-relative path doesn't exist (either a TLD or a JAR file with a taglib.tld in META-INF), a translation error will occur.
JSP containers must not alter their behavior based on the content, the presence, or the absence of a particular Tag or Tag Library Extension Element.
JSP containers must consider invalid any tag library that specifies mustUnderstand='true' for any Tag or Tag Library Extension element.
assertion.comment: Marked untestable as container behavior in this case is not clear.

assertion.description: All attribute constraints as described in the TLD must be enforced by the container.
assertion.comment: Series of negative tests.

assertion.description: The following must hold true for all tag handlers defined as tag files:
The tag file implementation must keep a copy of the JspContext instance passed to it by the invoking page via setJspContext(). This is called the 'Invoking JSP Context'.

The tag file implementation must create and maintain a second instance of JspContext called a 'JSP Context Wrapper'. If the Invoking JSP Context is an instance of PageContext, the JSP Context Wrapper must also be an instance of PageContext.
For each infocation of the tag, the JSP Context Wrapper must present a clean page scope containing no initial elements.
All scopes other than the page scope must be identical to this in the Invoking JSP Context and must be modified accofidingly when updates are made to those scopes in the JSP Context Wrapper.
