Any modifications to the page scope, however, must not affect the Invoking JSP Context.
For each attribute declared and specified, a page-scoped variable must be created in the page scope of the JSP Context Wrapper.
The name of the variable must be the same as the declared attribute name.
The value of the variable must be the value of the attribute passed in during invocation.
For each attribute declared as optional and not specified, no page-scoped variable is created.
If the tag accepts dynamic attributes, then page-scoped variables must also be made available for each dynamic attribute passed in.
The 'pageContext' scripting variable must point to the JSP Context Wrapper instead of the Invoking JSP Context
The tag handler must behave as through a tag library descriptor entry was defined for it, in accordance with the tag, attribute, and variable directives that appear in the tag file translation unit.
If <jsp:forward> is used within a tag file, the generated tag handler must stop processing upon the return of RequestDispatcher.forward() and throw a javax.servlet.jsp.SkipPageException
assertion.comment: Package seems goofy. Since SkipPageException is for use with SimpleTagHandlers, shouldn't this be in the tagext package?

assertion.description: If a tag file invokes a Classic Tag Handler which returns SKIP_PAGE, from doEndTag() , tag file must terminate and SkipPageException must be thrown.
If a tag file invokes a Classic Tag Handler invokes a a Simple Tag Handler which throws SkipPageException, the tag file must terminate and SkipePageException must be thrown.
If a tag file invokes a Simple Tag Handler which throws a SkipPageException, processing must terminate with the tag file throwing a SkipPageException
In the case of either Simple or Classic Tag Handlers, the doFinally() method must be called on enclising tags that implement the TryCatchFinally interface before returning.
The doEndTag() methods of enclosing classic tags must not be called.
assertion.comment: Is this related to the assertion above RE: TryCatchFinally?

assertion.description: When a tag file attempts to invoke a classic tag handler (i.e one that implements the Tag interface), it must cast the JspContext passed to the SimpleTag into a PageContext
If the cast by a Simple Tag Handler of a JspContext to a PageContext fails, the invocation of the classic tag files, and a JspException must be thrown.
assertion.comment: TCK will never run outside of a servlet env. So the cast will always work.

assertion.description: Tag files can be packaged in the /META-INF/tags directory of a JAR file installed in the /WEB-INF/lib directory.
Any tags packaged in a JAR file must have a Tag Library Descriptor (TLD) present within the JAR file with each tag that is to be recognized by the container enumerated in the TLD.
Any tag files within a JAR file that are not defined within a TLD must be ignored by the container.
A tag library is considered invalid and must be rejected by the container if a <tag-file> element has a <name> subelement with the same content as a <name> subelement in a <tag> element.
assertion.comment: Marked untestable as 'rejected' is not defined.

assertion.description: Tag files can be packaged in the /WEB-INF/tags/ directory of a web application or a subdirectory thereof.

The JSP container must interpret the '/WEB-INF/tags/' directory and each subdirectory under it, as another implicitly defined tag library containing tag handlers defined by the tag files that appear in the directory.
The JSP container must generate an implicit tag library for each directory under and included /WEB-INF/tags/.
The tag library can only be imported via the tagdir attribute of the taglib directive.
The <tlib-version> element will be defined as 1.0
<short-name> is derived from the directory name that that tag file resides in.
The <tag-file> element is considered to exist for each tag file in this directory.
The <name> for each is the filename of the tag file, withouth the .tag extension
The <path> element for each is the path of the tag file, relative to the root of the web application.

Upon deployment, the JSP container must seach for and process all tag files appearing in these directories and subdirectories. In processing a tag file, the container makes the custom actions defined in these tags available to JSP files.
A translation error will occur of a page directive is present within a tag file.
The taglib directive is legal within Tag files. The semantics of the taglib directive within a tag file are identical to those of a JSP page.
The include directive is legal within Tag files. The semantics of the include directive within a tag file are identical to those of a JSP page.
If the included file contains syntax unsuitable for tag files, a translation error will occur.
The tag directive is only applicable to tag files. Any attempt to use the tag directive in a JSP page will result in a translation error.
The attribute directive is only applicable to tag files. Any attempt to use the attribute directive in a JSP page will result in a translation error.
The variable directive is only applicable to tag files. Any attempt to use the variable directive in a JSP page will result in a translation error.
The 'tag' directive is similar to the page directive, but applied to tag files instead of JSP's.
A translation unit can container more than one instance of the tag directive, all the attributes will apply to the complete translation unit (i.e. tag directives are position independent).
Unrecoginized attributes or values will result in a fatal translation error.
The 'display-name' attribute provides a short name that is intended to be displayed by tools.
Multiple 'display-name' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'body-content' attribute specifies the body content of this tag.
A valid value is 'empty' meaning no body.
A valid value is 'tagdependent'.
A valid value is 'scriptless'
If the 'body-content' attribute is not specified, it will default to 'scriptless'
Any other value provided to the 'body-content' attribute aside from 'empty', 'tagdependent', or 'scriptless' will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'body-content' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'dynamic-attributes' attribute indicates whether this tag supports additional attributes with dynamic sata.
If 'true', the generated tag handler must implement the javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.DynamicAttributes interface.
If 'false' the generated tag handler will not implement the javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.DynamicAttributes interface.
The default value is 'false'.
If any values are provided to the 'dynamic-attributes' attribute aside from 'true' or 'false' a translation error will occur.
Multiple 'dyanmic-attribute' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'small-icon' attribute specifies a relative path, from the tag source file, of an image file containg a small icon that can be used by tools.
If the 'small-icon' attribute is not specified, no icon will be used.
Multiple 'small-icon' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'large-icon' attribute specifies a relative path from the tag source file, of an image file containing a large icon that can be used by tools.
If the 'large-icon' attribute is not specified, no icon will be used.
Multiple 'large-icon' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'decription' attribute provides an arbitrary string that describes this tag.
If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.
Multiple 'description' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'example' attribute defines an arbitraty string describe the use of this action.
If the 'example' attribute is not specified, no example string will be available.
Multiple 'example' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'language' attribute specifies the scripting language used by the tag file.

All scripting languages, specifiable by the tag directive's 'language' attribute, must provide some implicit objects that a JSP page author can use in declarations, scriptlets, and expressions (see Section JSP.1.3.8 for list of available implicit objects)

All scripting languages, specifiable by the tag directive's 'language' attribute, must expose the Java technology object model to the script environment, especially implicit variables, JavaBeans components properties, and public methods.
It is a fatal translation error for a tag directive with a non-"java" language attribute to appear after the first scripting has been encountered.
The only required scripting language value for the 'language' attribute is "java".
Multiple 'language' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.

The 'import' attribute of the tag directive specifies the fully qualified Java programming language type name denoting a particular type, or of a package name following by the ".*" string, denoting all the public types declared in that package, that shall be imorted by the translated JSP page implementation and is thus available to the scripting language.
The default import list for a tag is java.lang.*, javax.servlet.*, javax.servlet.jsp.*, javax.servlet.http.*

The 'pageEncoding' attribute of the tag directive specifies the character encoding of the tag. The value is in the form of CHARSET which my be the IANA value for a character encoding. If no 'pageEncoding' attribute is specified, the default of ISO-8859-1 will be used.
assertion.comment: What about Tag files in XML?

assertion.description: Multiple 'pageEncoding' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'pageEncoding' attribute of the tag directive is not influenced at all by any global configuration present in the web.xml
The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute specified whether scripting elements are legal within the tag file.

The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of the tag directive, if false, disallows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit and will generate a translation error if they are present.
The default value for 'isScriptingEnabled' of the tag directive, if not specified, is true.
Any value other than 'true' or 'false' provided to the 'isScriptinEnabled' attribute will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the tag directive specifies whether or not the container should evaluate EL expressions.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive , if false, will result in EL expressions not being evaluated by the container.
The default value, if 'isELEnabled' is not specified, is true.
Any value other than 'true' or 'false' provided to the 'isELEnabled' attribute will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'isELEnabled' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The attribute directive is analogous to the <attribute> element in the Tag Library Descriptor, and allows for the declaration of custom action attributes.
The 'name' attribute specified the unique name of the attribute being declared.
A translation error will occur if the 'name' attribute is not specified.
A translation error will occur if mnore than one attribute directive appears in the same translation unit with the same name.
The 'required' attribute indicates whether or not the attribute must be present.
If 'true' the attribute is requried and a translation error will occur if the attribute is not provided.
If 'false', the attribute need not be present.
If the 'required' attribute is not specified, the value of 'false' will be assumed.

The 'fragment' attribute specifies whether this attribute is a fragment to be evaluated by the tag handler or a normal attribute to be evaluated by the container prior to being passed to the tag handler.
If 'true', the type of the attribute is fixed to javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.JspFragment and a translation error will occur if the 'type' attribute is specified.
If 'true' the 'rtexprvalue' attribute is fixed at true.
A translation error will occur if the 'fragment' attribute is 'true' and the 'rtexprvalue' attribute is specified.
If 'false', the container will evaluate the attribute before passing it to the tag handler.
If the 'fragment' attribute is not specified, the behavior will be as if it was defined as 'false'
The 'rtexprevalue' attribute specifies whether this attribute accepts dynamic attribute value.
If 'true', the attribute can accept dynamic values.
If 'false', the attribute cannot accept a dynamic value. Any attempt to pass a dynamic value when false will result in a translation error.
If 'rtexprvalue' is not specified, the default of 'false' will be assumed.
A translation error will occur if any other value outside of 'true' or 'false' is provided.
The 'type' attribute specifies the runtime type of the attribute being described.
If the 'type' attribute is not specified, the default of java.lang.String will be assumed.
The 'description' attribute specifies a description of the attribute.
If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.
The variable directive is analogous to the <variable> element in the Tag Library Descriptor, and defines the details of a variable exposed by the tag handler to the calling page.
The 'name-given' attribute specifies the name of the scriptin variable to be exposed by the tag.
A translation error will occur if two variable directives have the same value for the 'name-given' attribute.
The 'name-from-attribute' directive specifies the name of an attribute whose (translation-time) value will give the name of the variable.
A translation error will occur if two variable directives have the same value for the 'name-from-attribute' attribute.
A translation error will occur if both the 'name-given' and the 'name-from-attribute' attributes are specified within the same directive.
A translation error will occur if neither the 'name-given' or the 'name-from-attribute' attributes are not specified wihin a variable directive.
The 'variable-class' attribute specifies the class of the variable.
If the 'variable-class' attribute is not specified, the default class of java.lang.String will be assumed.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of the variable being declared.
Valid values are AT_BEGIN, AT_END, or NESTED.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default scope of NESTED will be used.
If any other value is provided outside of AT_BEGIN, NESTED, or AT_END, a translation error will occur.
A translation error must occur if both 'scope' and 'fragment' are specified.
The 'declare' attribute specifies whether the variable is declared or not.
If 'true', the variable will be declared and available based on the specified scope.
If 'false', the variable will not be declared.
A translation error must occur if both 'declare' and 'fragment' are specified.
The 'fragment' attribute specifies that the value of this variable is scoped to the specified fragment and does not appear in the boyd of the tag.
A translation error will occur if the value of 'fragment' does not match the name of an attribute declared earier in this page with 'fragment=true'.
A translation error will occur if 'fragment' is specified and either 'scope' or 'declare' is specified.
The 'description' attribute provides an optional description for the variable being declared.
If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.
XML view of Tag Files
The XML equivalent of the tag directive is the jsp:directive.tag element. The semantics followed are the same as the tag directive in standard syntax.
A translation unit can contain more than one instance of the tag directive, all the attributes will apply to the complete translation unit (i.e. tag directives are position independent).

Multiple 'display-name' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.

If the 'body-content' attribute is not specified, it will default to 'scriptless'
Any other value provided to the 'body-content' attribute aside from 'empty', 'tagdependent', or 'scriptless' will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'body-content' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'dynamic-attributes' attribute indicates whether this tag supports additional attributes with dynamic sata.
If 'true', the generated tag handler must implement the javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.DynamicAttributes interface.
If 'false' the generated tag handler will not implement the javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.DynamicAttributes interface.
The default value is 'false'.

Multiple 'small-icon' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.

If the 'large-icon' attribute is not specified, no icon will be used.
Multiple 'large-icon' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.

If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.
Multiple 'description' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'example' attribute defines an arbitraty string describe the use of this action.
If the 'example' attribute is not specified, no example string will be available.
Multiple 'example' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'language' attribute specifies the scripting language used by the tag file.

All scripting languages, specifiable by the tag directive's 'language' attribute, must provide some implicit objects that a JSP page author can use in declarations, scriptlets, and expressions (see Section JSP.1.3.8 for list of available implicit objects)

All scripting languages, specifiable by the tag directive's 'language' attribute, must expose the Java technology object model to the script environment, especially implicit variables, JavaBeans components properties, and public methods.

assertion.description: Multiple 'pageEncoding' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'pageEncoding' attribute of the tag directive is not influenced at all by any global configuration present in the web.xml
The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute specified whether scripting elements are legal within the tag file.

The 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute of the tag directive, if false, disallows the presence of scripting elements (scriptlets, expressions, declarations) within a given translation unit and will generate a translation error if they are present.
The default value for 'isScriptingEnabled' of the tag directive, if not specified, is true.
Any value other than 'true' or 'false' provided to the 'isScriptinEnabled' attribute will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'isScriptingEnabled' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the tag directive specifies whether or not the container should evaluate EL expressions.
The 'isELEnabled' attribute of the page directive , if false, will result in EL expressions not being evaluated by the container.
The default value, if 'isELEnabled' is not specified, is true.
Any value other than 'true' or 'false' provided to the 'isELEnabled' attribute will result in a translation error.
Multiple 'isELEnabled' attribute/value (re)definitions will result in a translation error.
The attribute directive of a tag file can be described in XML using the jsp:directive.attribute element. The semantics of this element are the same as the attribute directive in standard syntax.
The 'name' attribute specified the unique name of the attribute being declared.
A translation error will occur if the 'name' attribute is not specified.
A translation error will occur if mnore than one attribute directive appears in the same translation unit with the same name.
The 'required' attribute indicates whether or not the attribute must be present.
If 'true' the attribute is requried and a translation error will occur if the attribute is not provided.
If 'false', the attribute need not be present.
If the 'required' attribute is not specified, the value of 'false' will be assumed.

The 'fragment' attribute specifies whether this attribute is a fragment to be evaluated by the tag handler or a normal attribute to be evaluated by the container prior to being passed to the tag handler.
If 'true', the type of the attribute is fixed to javax.servlet.jsp.tagext.JspFragment and a translation error will occur if the 'type' attribute is specified.
If 'true' the 'rtexprvalue' attribute is fixed at true.
A translation error will occur if the 'fragment' attribute is 'true' and the 'rtexprvalue' attribute is specified.
If 'false', the container will evaluate the attribute before passing it to the tag handler.
If the 'fragment' attribute is not specified, the behavior will be as if it was defined as 'false'
The 'rtexprevalue' attribute specifies whether this attribute accepts dynamic attribute value.
If 'true', the attribute can accept dynamic values.
If 'false', the attribute cannot accept a dynamic value. Any attempt to pass a dynamic value when false will result in a translation error.
If 'rtexprvalue' is not specified, the default of 'false' will be assumed.
A translation error will occur if any other value outside of 'true' or 'false' is provided.
The 'type' attribute specifies the runtime type of the attribute being described.
If the 'type' attribute is not specified, the default of java.lang.String will be assumed.
The 'description' attribute specifies a description of the attribute.
If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.
The variable directive of a tag file can be described in XML using the jsp:directive.variable element. The semantics are the same as the variable directive in standard syntax.
The 'name-given' attribute specifies the name of the scriptin variable to be exposed by the tag.
A translation error will occur if two variable directives have the same value for the 'name-given' attribute.
The 'name-from-attribute' directive specifies the name of an attribute whose (translation-time) value will give the name of the variable.
A translation error will occur if two variable directives have the same value for the 'name-from-attribute' attribute.
A translation error will occur if both the 'name-given' and the 'name-from-attribute' attributes are specified within the same directive.
A translation error will occur if neither the 'name-given' or the 'name-from-attribute' attributes are not specified wihin a variable directive.
The 'variable-class' attribute specifies the class of the variable.
If the 'variable-class' attribute is not specified, the default class of java.lang.String will be assumed.
The 'scope' attribute specifies the scope of the variable being declared.
Valid values are AT_BEGIN, AT_END, or NESTED.
If the 'scope' attribute is not specified, the default scope of NESTED will be used.
If any other value is provided outside of AT_BEGIN, NESTED, or AT_END, a translation error will occur.
A translation error must occur if both 'scope' and 'fragment' are specified.
The 'declare' attribute specifies whether the variable is declared or not.
If 'true', the variable will be declared and available based on the specified scope.
If 'false', the variable will not be declared.
A translation error must occur if both 'declare' and 'fragment' are specified.
The 'fragment' attribute specifies that the value of this variable is scoped to the specified fragment and does not appear in the boyd of the tag.
A translation error will occur if the value of 'fragment' does not match the name of an attribute declared earier in this page with 'fragment=true'.
A translation error will occur if 'fragment' is specified and either 'scope' or 'declare' is specified.
The 'description' attribute provides an optional description for the variable being declared.
If the 'description' attribute is not specified, no description will be available.

A JSP page is valid for a Java Platform if and only if the JSP page implementation class, together with any other classes defined by the JSP container, is a valid program for the given Java Platform, and if it passes the validation methods for all the tag libraries associated with the JSP page.
In JSP 2.0 only 'init' and 'destroy' events are allowed events.
A JSP page author may provide a jspInit() method, which if present, must be called by the container to prepare the page before the first request is delivered.
A JSP page author may provide a jspDestroy() method that can be called by a Container, when a request is not being serviced by the JSP page, to reclaim resources.
A translation error will occur if a JSP page author attempts to override any Servlet methods through a declaration scripting element.
assertion.comment: Reference 10.2.4 -- All methods in defined by the javax.servlet.Servlet interface are declared final.

assertion.description: The enforcement of the contract between the JSP container and the JSP page author is aided by the requirement that the Servlet class corresponding to the JSP page must implement the HttpJspPage interface if the protocol is HTTP.

The enforcement of the contract between the JSP container and the JSP page author is aided by the requirement that the Servlet class corresponding to the JSP page must implement the JspPage interface of the protocol in not HTTP.
The name of the JSP implementation class is implementation dependent.
The package that the JSP implementation class belongs to is implementation depenedent.
All JSP implementation classes must implement the following methods
assertion.comment: reflection baby!

assertion.description: Method with signature: public void jspInit()
Method with signature: public void jspDestroy()

Method with signature: public void _jspService(<ServletRequestSubType>, <ServletResponseSubType>) throws IOException, ServletException -- NOTE: The request/response subtype indicates that the request and response object provided must implement the javax.servlet.ServletRequest and javax.servlet.ServletResponse interfaces respectively.
The _jspService(ServletRequest, ServletResponse) method may not be declared in a JSP page via the JSP declaration mechanism.

JSP containers that conform to this specification (in both JSP page implementation classes, and JSP container runtime) must implement the javax.servlet.ServletRequest and javax.servlet.ServletResponse interfaces.
assertion.comment: XXX Sent request for clarification on this one

assertion.description: All JSP 2.0 compliant containers must support a simple precompilation protocol, as well as some basic reserved parameter names.
A request to a page with the request parameter 'jsp_precompile" is a precompilation request.
If the value of the request parameter 'jsp_precompile' is 'true' the request will not be delivered to the target page.
If the value of the request parameter 'jsp_precompile' is 'false', the request will not be delivered to the target page.
If the value of the request parameter 'jsp_precompile' is 'debug', the request will not be delivered to the target page.
If the value of the request parameter 'jsp_precompile' is empty (i.e. ""), the request will not be delivered to the target page.
If the value of the request parameter 'jsp_precompile' is any other value aside from 'true', 'false', 'debug', or an empty parameter, a translation error will occur.
All JSP 2.0 containers must implement JSR-045 by generating source map debugging information for JSP pages written in either standard or XML syntax.

The JSP compiler, when producing a class with JSP-045 debug extensions must produce a .class file with a SourceDebugExtension attribute, mapping each lione or lines of JSP code to the corresponding generated line or lines of Java code.
The strata, as defined by JSP-045, that maps to the original JSP source must be named JSP in the Source Debug Extension.
